_**Star Wars: The Clone Wars**_ is a 2008 American [3D
animated](/wiki/3D_animation "3D animation") [science
fiction](/wiki/Science_fiction "Science fiction")-[space
opera](/wiki/Space_opera "Space opera") film that takes place within the
_[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star Wars")_ saga, leading into a [TV series of
the same name](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(2008_TV_series\) "Star Wars:
The Clone Wars \(2008 TV series\)") produced by [Lucasfilm
Animation](/wiki/Lucasfilm_Animation "Lucasfilm Animation"). The film is set
during the three-year time period between the films _[Star Wars: Episode II –
Attack of the
Clones](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_II_%E2%80%93_Attack_of_the_Clones "Star Wars:
Episode II – Attack of the Clones")_ (2002) and _[Star Wars: Episode III –
Revenge of the
Sith](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_%E2%80%93_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars:
Episode III – Revenge of the Sith")_ (2005). Distributed by [Warner Bros.
Pictures](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros."), which also holds the home media
distribution rights to both this film and the first five seasons of the
television series, the film premiered on August 10, 2008 at the [Grauman's
Egyptian Theatre](/wiki/Grauman%27s_Egyptian_Theatre "Grauman's Egyptian
Theatre"), while screening in wide-release on August 14, 2008 across
Australia, and August 15 in the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom.
_The Clone Wars_ served as an introduction to the television series of the
same name, which debuted on October 3, 2008. Though critical reception was
negative, the film was a box office success, and grossed $68.3 million
worldwide against an $8.5 million budget.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

During the [Clone Wars](/wiki/Clone_Wars_\(Star_Wars\) "Clone Wars \(Star
Wars\)"), [Jedi Knights](/wiki/Jedi "Jedi") [Anakin
Skywalker](/wiki/Darth_Vader "Darth Vader") and [Obi-Wan Kenobi](/wiki/Obi-
Wan_Kenobi "Obi-Wan Kenobi") lead a small [Republic](/wiki/Galactic_Republic
"Galactic Republic") [clone army](/wiki/Clone_troopers "Clone troopers")
against the Separatist droid army on the planet
[Christophsis](http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Christophsis
"wookieepedia:Christophsis"). Awaiting reinforcements, the two Jedi greet a
shuttle carrying the young Jedi [Ahsoka Tano](/wiki/Ahsoka_Tano "Ahsoka
Tano"), who insists that she has been assigned by Jedi Master
[Yoda](/wiki/Yoda "Yoda") to serve as Anakin's Padawan. Anakin begrudgingly
accepts Ahsoka's apprenticeship, and the two succeed in deactivating the
Separatists' energy field while Obi-Wan stalls the droid army commander,
allowing a Republic victory. Ahsoka earns Anakin's respect.

Following the battle, Yoda arrives and informs the Jedi that crime lord [Jabba
the Hutt](/wiki/Jabba_the_Hutt "Jabba the Hutt")'s son Rotta has been
kidnapped. Anakin and Ahsoka are tasked with retrieving the Huttlet, while
Obi-Wan is sent to [Tatooine](/wiki/Tatooine "Tatooine") to negotiate with
Jabba over a potential treaty between the Hutts and the Republic. Anakin and
Ahsoka find Rotta on the planet Teth, where they are ambushed by Separatist
forces led by [Count Dooku](/wiki/Count_Dooku "Count Dooku")'s apprentice
[Asajj Ventress](/wiki/Asajj_Ventress "Asajj Ventress"), discovering that
Dooku hopes to frame the Jedi for Rotta's kidnapping. The Jedi manage to
escape the trap along with [R2-D2](/wiki/R2-D2 "R2-D2") and hijack a derelict
transport with which they travel to Tatooine. Obi-Wan, alerted by Anakin,
arrives on Teth and defeats Ventress in a [lightsaber](/wiki/Lightsaber
"Lightsaber") duel, though she manages to escape.

Meanwhile, Senator [Padmé Amidala](/wiki/Padm%C3%A9_Amidala "Padmé Amidala"),
Anakin's secret wife, learns of Anakin's mission and fears for his safety. She
decides to contact Jabba's uncle [Ziro](/wiki/Hutt_\(Star_Wars\)#Ziro_the_Hutt
"Hutt \(Star Wars\)") in Coruscant. The Hutt refuses to cooperate, apparently
believing that it is the Jedi who are responsible for the situation. However,
Padmé soon discovers that Ziro has actually conspired with Dooku to have Rotta
killed in order for Jabba to have Anakin and Ahsoka executed in return, which
will force the Jedi Council, led by Yoda, to take Jabba into custody and allow
Ziro to seize power over the Hutt clans. Padmé is discovered and detained, but
a chance call by [C-3PO](/wiki/C-3PO "C-3PO") enables her to summon a squadron
of clone troopers, and Ziro is arrested.

Upon their arrival on Tatooine, Anakin and Ahsoka are shot down by
[MagnaGuards](/wiki/MagnaGuards "MagnaGuards"). Anakin devises a ruse to
confront Dooku while carrying a decoy Rotta, leaving Ahsoka to take the real
Rotta to Jabba's palace. While Anakin fights off Dooku, Ahsoka is ambushed by
the MagnaGuards, whom she defeats. The two deliver Rotta safely to Jabba, who
nonetheless orders the Jedi's execution for their supposed attempt to kidnap
him. However, Padmé contacts Jabba in time and reveals Ziro and the
Separatists' responsibility for the kidnapping. Acknowledging the Jedi's
heroism and allowing the Republic to have Ziro punished for his betrayal,
Jabba agrees to the Republic treaty while Anakin and Ahsoka are retrieved by
Obi-Wan and Yoda. In the meantime during his escape, Dooku reports to his
master [Darth Sidious](/wiki/Palpatine "Palpatine") about the failure of their
plot against the Jedi and Jabba, but the Sith Lord assures to him that the
tide of war is still in their favor.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dave_Filoni.jpg/170px-
Dave_Filoni.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dave_Filoni.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dave_Filoni.jpg "Enlarge")

Director [Dave Filoni](/wiki/Dave_Filoni "Dave Filoni")

_Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ was made to serve as both a stand-alone story and
a lead-in to the weekly [animated TV series of the same
name](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(2008_TV_series\) "Star Wars: The Clone
Wars \(2008 TV series\)").[4] [George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George
Lucas") had the idea for a film after viewing some of the completed footage of
the early episodes on the big
screen.[[1]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)#endnote_)
Those first few episodes, originally planned for release on television, were
then woven together to form the theatrical
release.[[2]](//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)#endnote_)
The story of the kidnapped Hutt was inspired by the [Sonny
Chiba](/wiki/Sonny_Chiba "Sonny Chiba") samurai film titled _Shogun’s
Shadow_.[7] [Warner Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.") had tracked the
series' development from the beginning, and Lucas decided on a theatrical
launch after viewing early footage[8] declaring "This is so beautiful, why
don't we just go and use the crew and make a feature?"[9] Lucas described the
film was "almost an afterthought."[9] [Howard Roffman](/wiki/Howard_Roffman
"Howard Roffman"), president of Lucas Licensing, said of the decision,
"Sometimes George works in strange ways."[10] Producer [Catherine
Winder](/wiki/Catherine_Winder "Catherine Winder") said the sudden decision
added to an already large challenge of establishing a show "of this
sophistication and complexity,"[11] but she felt it was a good way to start
the series, and thought budgetary constraints forced the production team to
[think outside the box](/wiki/Thinking_outside_the_box "Thinking outside the
box") in a positive way.[11]

###
Animation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Animation")]

[Lucasfilm](/wiki/Lucasfilm "Lucasfilm") and [Lucasfilm
Animation](/wiki/Lucasfilm_Animation "Lucasfilm Animation") used
[Autodesk](/wiki/Autodesk "Autodesk") software to animate both the film and
the series using the [Maya](/wiki/Maya_\(software\) "Maya \(software\)") [3D
modeling](/wiki/3D_modeler "3D modeler") program to create highly detailed
worlds, characters and creatures.[12] The film's animation style was designed
to pay homage to the stylized looks of both Japanese anime and
[manga](/wiki/Manga "Manga"), and the
[supermarionation](/wiki/Supermarionation "Supermarionation") of the British
1960s series _[Thunderbirds](/wiki/Thunderbirds_\(TV_series\) "Thunderbirds
\(TV series\)")_. At a [Cartoon Network](/wiki/Cartoon_Network "Cartoon
Network")-hosted discussion, Lucas said he did not want the _Clones Wars_ film
or television series to look like such movies as
_[Beowulf](/wiki/Beowulf_\(2007_film\) "Beowulf \(2007 film\)")_ , because he
wanted a stylized look rather than a realistic one. He also felt it should not
look like the popular [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") movies such as _[The
Incredibles](/wiki/The_Incredibles "The Incredibles")_ , because he wanted the
film and characters to have its own unique style.[13] Lucas also decided to
create the animated film and series from a live-action perspective, which
Winder said set it apart from other CGI films. Essentially, it "meant using
long camera shots, aggressive lighting techniques, and relying on editing
instead of storyboards."[11] Animators also reviewed designs from the
[original 2003 _Clone Wars_
series](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Clone_Wars_\(2003_TV_series\) "Star Wars: Clone Wars
\(2003 TV series\)") when creating the animation style for the film and the
new series.[14] In charge was Steward Lee, working as the storyboard artist
during filming.[8] Some actors from the live-action films, including [Anthony
Daniels](/wiki/Anthony_Daniels "Anthony Daniels"), [Matthew
Wood](/wiki/Matthew_Wood_\(sound_editor\) "Matthew Wood \(sound editor\)"),
[Christopher Lee](/wiki/Christopher_Lee "Christopher Lee") and [Samuel L.
Jackson](/wiki/Samuel_L._Jackson "Samuel L. Jackson"), returned to vocally
reprise their roles of their respective characters,[15] although they didn't
reprised their roles in the subsequent _Clone Wars_ series.

The [musical score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") for _Star Wars: The Clone
Wars_ was composed by [Kevin Kiner](/wiki/Kevin_Kiner "Kevin Kiner").[16] The
original motion picture soundtrack was released by [Sony
Classical](/wiki/Sony_Classical "Sony Classical") on August 12, 2008. The disc
begins with the [main theme](/wiki/Star_Wars_music "Star Wars music") by [John
Williams](/wiki/John_Williams "John Williams"), followed by more than 30
separate music cues composed by Kiner.[16] Kiner is known for his work on such
television series as _[Stargate SG-1](/wiki/Stargate_SG-1 "Stargate SG-1")_ ,
_[Star Trek: Enterprise](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Enterprise "Star Trek: Enterprise")_
, _[Superboy](/wiki/Superboy_\(TV_series\) "Superboy \(TV series\)")_ and
_[CSI: Miami](/wiki/CSI:_Miami "CSI: Miami")_. The soundtrack uses some
[instruments](/wiki/Musical_instrument "Musical instrument") never heard
before in a _Star Wars_ score, including [erhus](/wiki/Erhu "Erhu"),
[duduks](/wiki/Duduk "Duduk") and [ouds](/wiki/Oud "Oud").[17]

##
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Marketing")]

###
Toys[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Toys")]

_Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ merchandise was first released on July 26, 2008.
[Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro "Hasbro") released several 3 3⁄4-inch _Clone Wars_
[action figures](/wiki/Action_figure "Action figure"), an electronic clone
trooper helmet, a customizable lightsaber, and an electronic [All Terrain
Tactical Enforcer (AT-TE)](/wiki/Walker_\(Star_Wars\) "Walker \(Star
Wars\)").[18] [Toys "R" Us](/wiki/Toys_%22R%22_Us "Toys "R" Us") mounted
digital clocks in all 585 of its stores that counted down to the release of
the _Clone Wars_ toys, and more than 225 of the stores opened at midnight for
the debut of the _Star Wars_ products. Two of the Toys "R" Us flagship outlets
in [Mission Bay, San Diego](/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Diego,_California "Mission
Bay, San Diego, California") and [Times Square](/wiki/Times_Square "Times
Square") in [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan"), New York City held
costume and trivia contests on July 26, and gave away limited-edition _Star
Wars_ toys with every purchase. A section of the Toys "R" Us website was also
dedicated to _The Clone Wars_.[10] The toy line continues with The Clone Wars
figures being well received by collectors for their detail to the characters
and vehicles.

###
Food[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Food")]

Due to Lucas's sudden decision to produce the film, Lucas Licensing did not
have time to enter into agreements with previous _Star Wars_ marketing
partners like [Pepsi](/wiki/Pepsi "Pepsi"), [Burger King](/wiki/Burger_King
"Burger King") and [Kellogg's](/wiki/Kellogg_Company "Kellogg Company"), with
which the Lucasfilm licensing company had a ten-year marketing plan for the
other films. When questioned by _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times
"The New York Times")_ about _Star Wars_ merchandising in July 2006, a Pepsi
spokesperson was unaware a new _Star Wars_ film was being released.
[Target](/wiki/Target_Corporation "Target Corporation") and [KB
Toys](/wiki/KB_Toys "KB Toys") also devoted shelf space for _Clone Wars_ toys,
but did not hold midnight releases or pursue the branding opportunities Toys
"R" Us did. On August 15, [McDonald's](/wiki/McDonald%27s "McDonald's") held
its first ever [Happy Meal](/wiki/Happy_Meal "Happy Meal") promotion for a
_Star Wars_ film and for four weeks, 18 exclusive toys came in specially
designed Happy Meal boxes.[10]

### Comics and
books[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Comics and books")]

[Dark Horse Comics](/wiki/Dark_Horse_Comics "Dark Horse Comics") published a
six-issue [digest-sized](/wiki/Digest-sized "Digest-sized") [comic book
miniseries](/wiki/Comic_book "Comic book"). Randy Stradley, vice president of
publishing for Dark Horse, said the sudden decision to release the _Clone
Wars_ film required the company to temporarily delay plans for two other _Star
Wars_ comic book series, _[Dark Times](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Dark_Times "Star Wars:
Dark Times")_ and _Rebellion_. The _Clone Wars_ comics did not receive the
promotional campaign it otherwise would have due to the abruptness of the
theatrical and comic book releases.[19] [Topps](/wiki/Topps "Topps"), the
[trading cards](/wiki/Trading_card "Trading card") company, released a series
of 90 _Clone Wars_ cards on July 26, which also included foil cards, motion
cards, animation cel cards and rare sketch cards by top _Star Wars_ artists
and Lucasfilm animators.[20] [DK Publishing](/wiki/DK_Publishing "DK
Publishing") and the [Penguin Group](/wiki/Penguin_Group "Penguin Group")
released books, activities and other merchandise that tied in with the film.
Also released was the _Clone Wars: The Visual Guide_ , published by DK, and
_Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ in the UK, published by Puffin and in the U.S. by
Grosset & Dunlap. The publishers also released a storybook, picture books and
an activity book.[21] At the [American International Toy
Fair](/wiki/American_International_Toy_Fair "American International Toy
Fair"), [Lego](/wiki/Lego "Lego") announced a product line for the film and
the TV series, to be released in July 2008 in the United States and on August
2008 in the United Kingdom.[22]

### Video
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Video games")]

The [LucasArts](/wiki/LucasArts "LucasArts") [video game
developer](/wiki/Video_game_developer "Video game developer") adapted the film
into _[Star Wars: The Clone Wars – Jedi
Alliance](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_%E2%80%93_Jedi_Alliance "Star Wars:
The Clone Wars – Jedi Alliance")_ for the [Nintendo DS](/wiki/Nintendo_DS
"Nintendo DS") and _[Star Wars: The Clone Wars – Lightsaber
Duels](/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_%E2%80%93_Lightsaber_Duels "Star Wars:
The Clone Wars – Lightsaber Duels")_ for [Wii](/wiki/Wii "Wii").[23] A
reviewer from PocketGamer.co.uk said his expectations for _Jedi Alliance_ were
low due to poor _Clone Wars_ movie reviews, but he found the game "a varied
and well-paced experience."[24]

### Portable media
players[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Portable media players")]

A _Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ [MP3 player](/wiki/Digital_audio_player "Digital
audio player") was released in August 2008. The player includes one gigabyte
of memory, which holds 200 songs or 20 hours of music and comes with three
interchangeable faceplates: a green one with Yoda and a lightsaber on it, a
silver one with Captain Rex and a [Galactic
Empire](/wiki/Galactic_Empire_\(Star_Wars\) "Galactic Empire \(Star Wars\)")
logo on it, and one with two [Clone troopers](/wiki/Clone_trooper "Clone
trooper") on [Coruscant](/wiki/Coruscant "Coruscant"). One review claimed it
improved upon a Darth Vader MP3 player released in July 2008, which featured
only 512 [megabytes](/wiki/Megabyte "Megabyte") of memory and a dated visual
display.[25] A _Star Wars_ [iPod](/wiki/IPod "IPod") iSpeaker (a speaker/dock
for iPods, [iPhones](/wiki/IPhone "IPhone") and MP3 players) was also
released. The speaker includes an image of Captain Rex and three other Clone
Troopers.[26]

### Racing
sponsorship[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Racing sponsorship")]

A _Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ [open wheel car](/wiki/Open_wheel_car "Open
wheel car") for the [IndyCar Series](/wiki/IndyCar_Series "IndyCar Series")
was unveiled at the 2008 San Diego [Comic-Con International](/wiki/Comic-
Con_International "Comic-Con International"). The #26 car, which also included
[Blockbuster Inc.](/wiki/Blockbuster_Inc. "Blockbuster Inc.") decals and was
driven by [Andretti Green Racing](/wiki/Andretti_Green_Racing "Andretti Green
Racing") driver [Marco Andretti](/wiki/Marco_Andretti "Marco Andretti"), ran
August 24 on the [Infineon Raceway](/wiki/Infineon_Raceway "Infineon Raceway")
in the [Sonoma Mountains](/wiki/Sonoma_Mountains "Sonoma Mountains") in
California. Andretti said, "I'm hoping that my upcoming battle at Infineon
will be as exciting as anything in a _Star Wars_ movie so I can win it for
both Blockbuster and Lucasfilm."[27] The car finished 14th at Infineon, which
Andretti attributed to a slow [pit stop](/wiki/Pit_stop "Pit stop") early in
the race; he added, "I just don't think it was a very good performance for us
today."[28] The _Clone Wars_ car was the second collaboration between
Lucasfilm, Blockbuster and Andretti Green Racing. It premiered as an _[Indiana
Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal
Skull](/wiki/Indiana_Jones_and_the_Kingdom_of_the_Crystal_Skull "Indiana Jones
and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull")_ car at the [Indianapolis
500](/wiki/Indianapolis_500 "Indianapolis 500") in May 2008.[27]

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Home media")]

The film's two-disc [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") and [Blu-ray Disc](/wiki/Blu-
ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") was released on November 11, 2008 in the United
States and on December 8, 2008 in the United Kingdom.[29][30] The film was
released as a single-disc DVD, two-disc Special Edition DVD, and Blu-ray Disc.
The standard-definition versions include the film in widescreen format with
Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround EX sound, and with feature-length audio
commentary.[31]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Critical response")]

_Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ received an 18% approval rating based on 157
reviews compiled by [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes"). The site's critical consensus reads: "Mechanical animation and a
less-than stellar script make _The Clone Wars_ a pale shadow of [George
Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas")' once great franchise."[32] This
constituted the lowest Rotten Tomatoes rating of any _Star Wars_ film; the
previous six theatrical films ranged from 55% to 94%, and the made-for-
television [Ewok](/wiki/Ewok "Ewok") films and the _[Star Wars Holiday
Special](/wiki/Star_Wars_Holiday_Special "Star Wars Holiday Special")_
garnered higher ratings, although their averages encompassed far fewer
reviews.[32] At [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film scored
35% based on 30 reviews, indicating "generally unfavorable reviews."[33]

_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_
listed _Star Wars: The Clone Wars_ as one of the five worst films of 2008[34]
with critic [Owen Gleiberman](/wiki/Owen_Gleiberman "Owen Gleiberman") saying,

> It's hard to tell the droids from the Jedi drones in this robotic animated
> dud, in which the George Lucas Empire Strikes Back—at the audience. What
> wears you out is Lucas' immersion in a Star Wars cosmology that has grown so
> obsessive-compulsively cluttered yet trivial that it's no longer escapism;
> Because this movie has bad lightsaber duels and the lack of the original
> cast, it's something you want to escape from.[34]

_[Ain't It Cool News](/wiki/Ain%27t_It_Cool_News "Ain't It Cool News")_ posted
two reviews of the film during the week before its release, but pulled them
down due to an embargo placed on those attending the screening its writers
attended. The same reviews were re-posted on the site, on the day of the
film's release. The retraction prompted some readers to allege a conspiracy by
Lucasfilm to keep negative press out of circulation until the release of the
film, but although the review by site creator [Harry
Knowles](/wiki/Harry_Knowles "Harry Knowles") was negative, [Drew
McWeeny](/wiki/Drew_McWeeny "Drew McWeeny") said that his review was positive
and that no such conspiracy existed.[35]

Several critics compared _The Clone Wars_ to a [Saturday morning
cartoon](/wiki/Saturday_morning_cartoon "Saturday morning
cartoon")[36][37][38] and described it as little more than a plug for the
upcoming animated series.[39][40][41] Linda Barnard, of the _[Toronto
Star](/wiki/Toronto_Star "Toronto Star")_ , said the movie "pretty much drives
a stake into the heart of every loyal fan of the movies. And now [George Lucas
is] out to stick it to those too young to know about [Jar Jar
Binks](/wiki/Jar_Jar_Binks "Jar Jar Binks")."
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_
[magazine](/wiki/Magazine "Magazine") reviewer Todd McCarthy said, "This isn't
the _Star Wars_ we've always known and at least sometimes loved."[40] Joe
Neumiar, of the _[New York Daily News](/wiki/Daily_News_\(New_York\) "Daily
News \(New York\)")_ , wrote, "If this were a true _Star Wars_ film, right
about now somebody would say, '...I've got a bad feeling about this.'"[42] In
his review for _Entertainment Weekly_ , critic Owen Gleiberman gave the film
an [F grade](/wiki/Grade_\(education\)#United_States "Grade \(education\)")
and wrote, "George Lucas is turning into the enemy of fun."[43] Carrie Rickey,
of _[The Philadelphia Inquirer](/wiki/The_Philadelphia_Inquirer "The
Philadelphia Inquirer")_ , said, "The best that can be said about the movie is
that it's harmless and mostly charmless. _The Clone Wars_ is to _Star Wars_
what [karaoke](/wiki/Karaoke "Karaoke") is to pop music."[41]

Remember how people talked about the _Star Wars_ prequels like they were the
worst movies ever made, when really, come on, they weren't THAT bad? _The
Clone Wars_ actually IS that bad.  
---  
— Film critic, Eric D. Snider[44]  
  
The main criticism toward the film was the animation. Many criticized it as
cheap, wooden, non-engaging, and out-of-date;[36][37][39][40][41][45][46] some
reviewers drew negative comparisons to 1960s [marionette](/wiki/Marionette
"Marionette")-based shows _Thunderbirds_ and _[Fireball
XL5](/wiki/Fireball_XL5 "Fireball XL5")_ ,[39][42][46][47] although George
Lucas previously said the animation style was a deliberate homage to such
shows.[13] Tom Long of _[The Detroit News](/wiki/The_Detroit_News "The Detroit
News")_ said the animation "is downright weak compared to what's generally
seen on screens these days"[48] and said the characters are so stiff they look
like they were "carved by [Pinocchio](/wiki/Pinocchio "Pinocchio")'s
[father](/wiki/Mister_Geppetto "Mister Geppetto")."[48] [Roger
Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") said "the characters have hair that
looks molded from [Play-Doh](/wiki/Play-Doh "Play-Doh"), bodies that seem
arthritic, and moving lips on half-frozen faces—all signs that shortcuts were
taken in the animation work."[37] McCarthy said "the movements, both of the
characters and the compositions, look mechanical, and the mostly familiar
characters have all the facial expressiveness of [Easter Island
statues](/wiki/Moai "Moai")." But some of the same reviewers who criticized
the animation acknowledged some positive elements about it; McCarthy said it
allowed for "somewhat more dramatic compositions and color schemes,"[40] and
Carrie Rickey, of _The Philadelphia Inquirer_ , said the scenery and
backgrounds were "vivid and alive",[41] although she said the characters "move
as you would imagine the statues at a [waxworks](/wiki/Wax_museum "Wax
museum") might."[40]

Reviewers also criticized the dialogue, which Ebert said was limited to
"simplistic declamations"[37] and Claudia Puig of _[USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today
"USA Today")_ described as "stilted and overblown, a problem also in some of
the live-action incarnations."[36] Many critics also said that the battle
scenes were repetitive and lacked tension;[36][37][40][43][49] McCarthy
described the action sequences as "a little exposition, an invasion; some more
exposition, a lightsaber fight; a bit more blah-blah, a spaceship
[dogfight](/wiki/Dogfight "Dogfight"), and on and on."[40] Linda Stasi, of the
_[New York Post](/wiki/New_York_Post "New York Post")_ , also described the
lack of character development in the film, writing that whereas the original
_Star Wars_ films dedicated time to allowing viewers to get to know the
characters, "Director Dave Filoni is so concentrated on the action that we're
never given the chance to care who lives and who is blown into spare
parts."[45] Jason Anderson, of the _[Globe and Mail](/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail
"The Globe and Mail")_ , wrote that although _The Clone Wars_ is intended for
younger audiences, "parents may be perturbed by the film's relentless
violence."[49] Ebert also found protagonist Ahsoka Tano "annoying,"[37] and
Michael Rechtshaffen, of _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ , said the
attempts of humor amid the bickering between Tano and Anakin Skywalker are
"strained".[46] Puig said she enjoyed the character, and that "her repartee
with Anakin enlivens things."[36]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Wars:_The_Clone_Wars_\(film\)&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Box office")]

_The Clone Wars_ earned $68,282,844 worldwide, including $35,161,554 in North
American domestic box office grosses and $33,121,290 in international
grosses.[3] The film earned $14,611,273 on 3,452 screens in its opening
weekend,[50] including $6,228,973 on its opening day, August 15.[51] It was
the third-highest earning film of the weekend, behind _[Tropic
Thunder](/wiki/Tropic_Thunder "Tropic Thunder")_ and _[The Dark
Knight](/wiki/The_Dark_Knight_\(film\) "The Dark Knight \(film\)")_ , which
earned $25.8 million and $16.3 million, respectively.[50] Dan Fellman, head of
distribution for Warner Bros., said the box office performance met
expectations because two-thirds of the audience were families and the budget
for the film was $8.5 million, frugal considering it was a CGI film, and
because the film was meant to introduce the animated series. Fellman said, "It
was targeted to a specific audience for specific reasons. We accomplished that
mission, and it will continue in another medium."[2] When _The Clone Wars_
dropped to $5.6 million in its second week of release, ContactMusic.com
described it as "the first bona fide _Star Wars_ flop."[52] The film also
earned $23,428,376 from DVD sales in the US.[53]
